bibl.title: Additions to an article in the Military Surgeon, October, 1927

div1.p: The writer corrects the date of the commencement of mosquito eradication in Havana.

div1.head: Additions to an article in the Military Surgeon, October, 1927
div1.opener:
Winter's Article
Mil. Surg. Oct. 1927
Romantic Conquest Y. F.
(Printer: This to go at end of article:)
div1.p:
“Note by Editor: The date of the beginning of the warfare against
Yellow Fever in Havana is epochal, and therefore of interest and importance.
The date, Feb. 4, 1901, given by General Winter, is from the final Report of
Gorgas as Chief Sanitary Officer of Havana (dated Washington, July 12, 1902)
and it seems certain that it was a clerical error. The reasons for thinking
so are that he was not at that time a convert to the mosquito theory, as for-
mulated by Reed, and in other articles he gives a later date. In the same
report, he states (page 3):

“In February, 1901, Dr. Reed read a paper before the
International Sanitary Congress in Habana giving the results
of their work. The idea was so new and so entirely contrary
to all former theories on the subject, and apparently to all
former theories on the subject, and apparently to all former
experience that the paper was received with scanty belief. I
myself had seen the work and was convinced that the mosquito
could convey yellow fever but I was hardly prepared to believe
that it was the only way or even the ordinary way of conveying
the disease.”

In a pamphlet prepared at the request of Surgeon General O'Reilly
for distribution to Medical and Sanitary Officers (A Few General Directions
With Regard to Destroying Mosquitoes, particularly the Yellow Fever Mosquito.
By W. C. Gorgas, Col. M. C., U.S. Army, Gov. Printing Office, 1904), Colonel
Gorgas states (page 10 speaking of house inspections for breeding places):

“At the first report on this subject, I think it was in
March, 1901, we found that we had in Havana in the neighborhood
of 26,000 different water deposits which contained wigglers, most
of them of the yellow fever variety.......The report of January,
1902, after about ten months of this mosquito work showed that
within the city limits less than 300 promises had wigglers upon
them”. (Italics in above quotations are the Editor's)

Reed gives the date of beginning work as February 15, and this
doubtless refers to the formulation of plans at Sanitary Headquarters rather
than the activities of mosquito squads in the patios of Havana. It is a
safe bet that any physical attack on the mosquito in the City of Havana before
the first of March, 1901 was limited to the ancient and automatic manual
response to the stimulus of a bite.
